comments.body: Yeah, we now need deliberate logic to "get back to the same union", so to speak. Previously it would happen automatically because we'd (non-deterministically) attach an alias to the union and then use it _everywhere_. In this particular case we could go either way, but we need additional logic to recognize that the two operations neutralize each other and produce the original union.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +37,41 @@    let pair2: Pairs<FooBar>[keyof FooBar] = {
        ~~~~~
!!! error TS2322: Type '{ key: "foo"; value: number; }' is not assignable to type '{ key: "foo"; value: string; } | { key: "bar"; value: number; }'.
!!! error TS2322:   Types of property 'value' are incompatible.
!!! error TS2322:     Type 'number' is not assignable to type 'string'.

comments.body: Also, kind of weird that it skips a level of elaboration, but that's out of scope here.

!!! error TS2322: Type '{ key: "foo"; value: number; }' is not assignable to type '{ key: "foo"; value: string; } | { key: "bar"; value: number; }'.
!!! error TS2322:   Types of property 'value' are incompatible.
!!! error TS2322:     Type 'number' is not assignable to type 'string'.
        key: "foo",
